title: Spheres Attached to String at an Angle

content.question: One end of a string is attached to the ceiling and the other end is attached to a small sphere traveling in a circular path, as shown above, with a constant speed of <math alttext="1 meter per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>m/</mtext><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The string makes an angle of <math alttext="30 degrees " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn><mi>Â°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to the vertical. If the tension in the string is <math alttext="6 newtons" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the circumference of the circle is <math alttext="1 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, how much work is done on the sphere by the string as the sphere travels through one revolution?
